answers.answer: Please post those so-called "normal" thyroid test results and their reference ranges shown on the lab report so that members can assess the adequacy of testing and comment on the doctor's interpretation.

sorry Im just now getting back to this question had a lot going on... My mother went for her ultra sound and now the radioactive scan had to convince the Dr. to these tests her free t3 (3.2)  range 2.3-4.2  total t4 (8.0) range4.5-10.9  tsh (0.95)  range 0.55-4.78. thank you

Her Free T3 is slightly below midpoint of the range.  This can sometimes be associated with hypothyroidism, because the range is far too broad.  Many of our members, myself included, report that symptom relief for them required that FT3 was adjusted into the upper part of its range and FT4 adjusted to around the midpoint of its range.   Not clear if you are looking for treatment for your mom, or just to understand if she is truly hypo.The answer to the question of being hypothyroid or not has to start with whether hypo symptoms are present.  This is a good link for you and your family to go through and determine that.http://thyroid.about.com/cs/basics_starthere/a/hypochecklist.htmIf hypo symptoms are apparent, then testing should be done for The thyroid antibodies, TPO ab and TG ab, to see if Hashimoto's Thyroiditis is pressent.  Hashi's is the most common cause of hypothyroidism.  In addition, testing should go beyond TSH and include the biologically active thyroid hormones, Free T3 and Free T4.   TSH is so variable that it is inadequate as a diagnostic for thyroid issues, so don't ever let a doctor stop with that or medicate you based on TSH alone.  Patients that are suspect as hypo also should be tested for Vitamin D, B12, iron/ferritin, zinc, selenium, and RBC magnesium.Sometimes doctors use "Reference Range Endocrinology" and will tell you that if a thyroid test falls anywhere within the reference range, that is adequate.  That is also wrong.  The ranges are far too broad,for reasons I won't get into right now.  FT3 and FT4 need to be high enough in their range to relieve any hypo symptoms.Going to an Endo does not guarantee a good thyroid doctor.  Many specialize in diabetes, and many others have the "Immaculate TSH Belief", or use "reference Range Endocrinology" and the patient suffers.  What you need most would be a good thyroid doctor.  By that I mean one that will treat clinically by testing and adjusting Free T3 and Free T4 as necessary to relieve symptoms, without being constrained by resultant TSH levels.  Symptom relief should be all important, not just test results.If you want more insight into clinical treatment, this is a link to a letter written by a good thyroid doctor for patients that he sometimes consults with from a distance.  The letter is sent to the PCP of the patient to ehlp guide treatment.http://hormonerestoration.com/files/ThyroidPMD.pdfIf your doctors don't qualify as good thyroid doctors and you need help locating one,  if you will tell us your location, perhaps a member could recommend one, based on personal experience.
